case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Trustees of J.K. Trust, Bombay

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Bombay High Court passed in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 and ss. 21 and 19 of the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940, and of the Business Profits Tax Act, 1947, respectively read with s. 66(1) of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds managing agency is business, and business is property within s.4(3)(i).

issues.text: Whether on the facts of the case the commission earned by the managing agents for managing the Raymond Woollen Mills was income earned by the managing agents for services rendered and not income derived from property held under trust or for other legal obligations and therefore not exempt under s. 4(3)(i) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of the case the commission earned by the managing agents for managing the Raymond Woollen Mills was income earned by the managing agents for services rendered and not income derived from property held under trust or for other legal obligations and therefore not exempt under s. 4(3)(i) of the Income-tax Act?

issues.text: Whether on the facts of the case the business carried on by the Trustees fall to be considered under s. 4(3)(i) or s. 4(3)(ia) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of the case the business carried on by the Trustees fall to be considered under s. 4(3)(i) or s. 4(3)(ia) of the Income-tax Act?

issues.text: whether the income received by the trustees of J.K. Trust, Bombay, as managing agents of Raymond Woollen Mills, Ltd., is income derived from property held on trust or on an obligation in the nature of trust

anchor.surface_text: The points that arise for determination in this appeal are  1  whether the income received by the trustees of J.K. Trust, Bombay, as managing agents of Raymond Woollen Mills, Ltd., is income derived from property held on trust or on an obligation in the nature of trust

issues.text: whether the claim for exemption in respect of such income is to be determined under s. 4(3)(i) or s. 4(3)(ia)

anchor.surface_text: and  2  whether the claim for exemption in respect of such income is to be determined under s. 4 3  i  or s. 4 3  ia .

anchor.surface_text: Whether a managing agency could be regarded as business was considered by this Court in Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad... it was held that it was business.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: religious or charitable institution when the income is applied solely to the purposes of the institution and -  a  the business is carries on in the c

arguments.court_reasoning: Clause 3 Ex.A authorizes; integral scheme; deposit as security; English cases on aid of fund.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a managing agency could be regarded as business was considered by this Court in Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad , where the question arose with reference to assessment of excess profits tax on the remuneration received by managing agents, tax being leviable under that Act only on business income and it was held that it was business, and that the profits therefrom were rightly assessed to tax under the Act. The law must therefore be taken to be settled beyond controversy that managing agency is itself business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent from Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. Government of Hyderabad holding managing agency remuneration assessable as business income under Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.text: property is a term of the widest import... Business would undoubtedly be property

anchor.surface_text: Now property is a term of the widest import, and subject to any limitation or qualification which the context might require, it signifies every possible interest which a person can acquire, hold and enjoy. Business would undoubtedly be property, unless there is something to the contrary in the enactment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'property' as broadest term including all interests; no restriction in s.4(3)(i) excluding business.

holdings.text: the word property in s. 4(3)(i) of the Act is of sufficient amplitude to comprehend business, and ... the managing agency constituted under Ex. B must be treated as property held on trust within s. 4(3)(i) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the word property in s. 4 3  i  of the Act is of sufficient amplitude to comprehend business, and if the question fell to be decided solely on the terms of that sub-section, the managing agency constituted under Ex. B must be treated as property held on trust within s. 4 3  i  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines textual breadth of 'property', precedents (Tribune PC, All India Spinners), trust via Ex.A cl.3 authorizing business with trust fund aid, integral Ex.A & B scheme, English cases on aid equating to employment.

holdings.text: even an office of trusteeship was held to be property especially when emoluments were attached to it, and that must a fortiori be the position in the case of office of managing agency

anchor.surface_text: In Angurbala Mullick v. Debabrata Mullick and The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt, even an office of trusteeship was held to be property especially when emoluments were attached to it, and that must a fortiori be the position in the case of office of managing agency, which is clearly one of profit and even alienable under certain circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows SC precedents Angurbala Mullick and Shirur Mutt holding offices with emoluments as property; managing agency profitable and alienable.

holdings.text: We must therefore hold that the fact that the trustees have the option at any time to throw up the managing agency is no legal impediment to its being property which could be held on trust

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore hold that the fact that the trustees have the option at any time to throw up the managing agency is no legal impediment to its being property which could be held on trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trust properties subject to incidents like terminability; charity perpetual via cy pres; s.77(c) Trusts Act on extinction only if no property left.

holdings.text: reading together Exs. A and B, it is impossible to resist the conclusion that both the documents formed part of an integral scheme

anchor.surface_text: But it is to be observed that clause 3 of the trust deed expressly provides for the acquisition of the business of managing agency on behalf of the trust and with the help of the trust fund, and that precisely is what has happened and indeed, reading together Exs. A and B, it is impossible to resist the conclusion that both the documents formed part of an integral scheme,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.A cl.3 authorizes managing agency with trust fund; deposit security; English precedents (Rocke v Hart, Moons v De Bernales) aid of fund = employment in business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a managing agency could be regarded as business was considered by this Court in Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad , where the question arose with reference to assessment of excess profits tax on the remuneration received by managing agents, tax being leviable under that Act only on business income and it was held that it was business, and that the profits therefrom were rightly assessed to tax under the Act. The law must therefore be taken to be settled beyond controversy that managing agency is itself business.
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 states property includes business as term of widest import, supporting concept c13 definition.

anchor.surface_text: Now property is a term of the widest import, and subject to any limitation or qualification which the context might require, it signifies every possible interest which a person can acquire, hold and enjoy. Business would undoubtedly be property, unless there is something to the contrary in the enactment.
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.

B must be treated as property held on trust within s. 4 3  i  of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In Angurbala Mullick v. Debabrata Mullick and The Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt, even an office of trusteeship was held to be property especially when emoluments were attached to it, and that must a fortiori be the position in the case of office of managing agency, which is clearly one of profit and even alienable under certain circumstances.
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.

anchor.surface_text: We must therefore hold that the fact that the trustees have the option at any time to throw up the managing agency is no legal impediment to its being property which could be held on trust.
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.

edges.explanation: h6 Ex A and B integral scheme supports h3 treating managing agency as trust property

anchor.surface_text: But it is to be observed that clause 3 of the trust deed expressly provides for the acquisition of the business of managing agency on behalf of the trust and with the help of the trust fund, and that precisely is what has happened and indeed, reading together Exs. A and B, it is impossible to resist the conclusion that both the documents formed part of an integral scheme,
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.
